content:
Equilibrium is stable when  $\mathbf{m}_{\mathrm{Q}}$  is parallel to  $\mathbf{B}_{\mathrm{P}}$ , and unstable when it is anti-parallel to  $\mathbf{B}_{\mathrm{P}}$ .

# EXAMPLE 5.2

For instance for the configuration  $\mathbf{Q}_3$  for which  $\mathbf{Q}$  is along the perpendicular bisector of the dipole  $\mathbf{P}$ , the magnetic moment of  $\mathbf{Q}$  is parallel to the magnetic field at the position 3. Hence  $\mathbf{Q}_3$  is stable. Thus,

(a)  $\mathrm{PQ}_1$  and  $\mathrm{PQ}_2$
(b) (i)  $\mathrm{PQ}_3$ ,  $\mathrm{PQ}_6$  (stable); (ii)  $\mathrm{PQ}_5$ ,  $\mathrm{PQ}_4$  (unstable)
(c)  $\mathrm{PQ}_6$
summary: Stability of equilibrium configurations depends on the orientation of the magnetic moment of Q with respect to the magnetic field at the position (P). When m_Q is parallel to B_P, equilibrium is stable, and when it is anti-parallel it is unstable.
hypothetical_questions: What happens to the stability of equilibrium configurations if the angle between m_Q and B_P is increased?
How does the orientation of the magnetic field of P affect the stability of Q's equilibrium?
Are there any configurations of Q for which the equilibrium is always unstable, regardless of the orientation of Q's magnetic moment?
